fol.8r
May it please your good L. The people of these c
o
treis,
and chiefly those of
Zeland,
have bin spoiled muche of late by
e shippes of warre of
Dunkerk
: wherby
e trafficke of their
marchants, and specially
e trade of
e fisherm
e
there is letted
exceedingly. For they of D
u
kerk are able to make to
e seas
8 very good shippes in warlicke sort, and
vide them very
thorowly of m
e
and muniti
o
. It is also understoode
t
e
Co
u
t of Arrembergh
is now at this inst
a
t a suitour in
Spaine
,
t
further force of shipping may be sent unto them. Which
all m
e
thinke they shall obtene. For
e
King
was ever carefull
both of keeping and increasing
e shipping of Dunkerk: as
hath appeared heeretofore by divers of his l
re
s, w
c
have bin
sent to
e
D. of Parma
, and intercepted in this c
o
trey. This
hath sturred those of Zeland, to looke in time into their state,
and to consult up
o
some meanes, to
p
vent
e danger
t
may
follow. For their fisherm
e
are many, and are not able
to c
o
tinue, if their fishing chance to faile:
t
if some
order be not tak
e
for their p
nt
reliefe, it is to be expected
t
they will mutine on
e soddaine, and it hath bin heere in
former times,
t
they have bin caried in suche cases w
t
a
violent revolt, so as no endevours would suffice to pacifie
their humours. To meete w
t
this mischief in time
c
o
venient, they c
a
finde no better course, then to imploye
all their forces, to c
o
quer
e towne. For though their
shippes
t
lie before it, doe somewhat stoppe their c
o
ming
fourth, yet they c
a
not lie there in
e deepe of
e winter:
and in sommer they c
a
not hinder, but many will abroade:
w
c
haps in c
o
tinu
a
ce may grow to suche a power, as
w
t
e aide of their neighbours in
Britaine
and
Flanders
,
they will be able to go thorow w
t
some singular exploit.
There are some of
t
Province,
t
come purposly hither
to acquaint
Co
u
t Maurice
w
t
this mater and some others
fol.8v
heere in
Holland
: to
e ende it may goe forwa[rd ]
assent a nd assistance of
e rest of
e Provinces [.]
it is but handled by way of privat c
o
munica
o
n a[.]
fewe of
e chiefest: who are able notw
t
standing [.]
suade w
t
e residue. The designe [.]
of Zeland for besieging
e towne is approv[ed by]
those to whom it is imparted. But these are [.]
doubtes
t
they cast in their conference. F[.]
I have written in my last to your L.
e resolu
o
n [.]
take by those of
Friseland
, to shut up
e passag[e of]
Groeningh
e
and
Linghen
: w
c
they hope they shall [be]
able, w
t
those troupes
t
they have of their owne rep[.]
as making little doubt of reducing
e towne, [.]
for their purpose in that behalf, and suffici
e
t supp[ly]
of re
q
sit
visi
o
, they have surcharged their Pro[vinces]
w
t
a speciall c
o
tribu
o
n, above
e extraordinary sum[mes]
w
c
they doe otherwise yeld, as
e rest of
e Provinces [.]
ding to their quote, to
e g
na
l charges of
e co[.]
So as where they were accustomed, to furnishe
w
t
3000 souldiers, there will be so many wanting [.]
this enterprise of Dunkerk. Secondly th[ose]
of Holland in their g
na
l meeting have determi[ned]
long agoe, to blocke up Gertrudenbergh: w
c
is [.]
to th
e
of so muche importance as your L. kno[weth]
And how
e townes will now be wonne, to put of [the]
attempt, it is somewhat to be doubted. [.]
could come so to passe,
t
both exploites might be [.]
there would be no
q
stion. But
t
up
o
Dunkerk [.]
a choise season, when
e seas are calmest, and [.]
heate of
e summer: so as hardly by c
o
jecture, [.]
after or before, there will be time suffici
e
t to [.]
w
t
Gertrudenbergh. Nevertheles it is priv[.]

c
o
cluded in this assembly of
e chiefest,
t
considering the
necessitie of subduing those of Dunkerk,
e townes shall be
moved to relent in some sort. For they will put in triall
w
t
all
e speede they c
a
devise, w
at
may be done against
Gertrudenbergh, before
e season serve for Dunkerk: and they
are not out of hope, to effect their desire. The
point of greatest considera
o
n, is how they shall be able
in regard of their meanes, to undertake
e siege of D
u
kerk.
For if they take it once in hand, they must come so
p
pared
as they may be well in state, to attend
e c
o
ming of
e Enemy.
Whereup
o
in
jecting w
at
is re
q
sit unto it, they doe recken
t
they must not be served w
t
fewer th
e
towardes 12000 foote
and 2000 horse. To make up
t
number, they may not
account to have any out of Frise, nor yet out of
Utrecht
,
Guelders
, and
Overyssel
(w
c
are all in one intent) unles
e forsaide passage betweene Groeningh
e
and Linghen
c
a
be stopped up before
e time, whereof
e apparance is
not great. All
e rest
at c
a
be spared out of Holland
and Zeland, and their garrisons left in good safetie, will
hardly reache to 6000 foote, and 1600 horse.
Heerup
o
they have agreed,
t
their purpose in this mater,
and their meanes to
fourme it, should be signified unto
me, and
t
I shold be re
q
sted to make it knowe unto her
M
tie
and to
pose in their behalf their petition unto her,
That her Hig
es
would be pleased, in considera
o
n of the
d
o
mages done to her subjectes, w
c
are like every day to
growe to be greater, and of
e irreparable inc
o
venience
t
may fall to these c
o
treis, if their fishing be impeached,
to assiste th
e
for so long as
e siege of Dunkerk shall
c
o
tinue, w
t
two or three thousand of her people, by whome
they are in hope not onely to attene, to be masters of
e
towne, but to make it a place of notable annoiance
to
e Enemies designes. They c
a
not
write, as they
fol.9v
would, to her Hig
es
themselves, because it is not [.]
to any publicke assembly: but I thinke they will ta[.]
t

r
Car[on .]
referring her Hig
es
to his declara
o
n. [I]
have likewise dealt w
t
M
r
Buzenval
, to advertise [.]
w
at
is meant to be done, and to intreate for all
e a[.]
his estate can affourde. They were also mind[ed]
as I am secretly told (but not w
t
their privitie, tho[ugh I]
know it for certaine) to move her M
tie
to gra
u
t [.]
Regim
e
t of 2000 Englishe souldiers for
e service [of]
these Provinces, to be heere intertened at
e Charges [of the]
c
o
trey, of whom they are desirous to c
o
stitute co[.]
S
r
Francis Vere
: whose cariage among th
e
, hath so fi[.]
humour of all sortes of people, and hath so much [.]
their affaires, for advise and for valour, as it see[meth]
by their speeches, it is most for his sake,
t
they [.]
to have
e Regiment: but so much the more, because [.]
that meanes in
e Enemies c
o
ceat, they shall be [.]
as heertofore to enjoy her Hig
es
succours in defense [of]
their cause, w
c
they know doeth much adv
a
tage [.]
co
u
tenance their actions. But for certaine they [.]
destitute of m
e
of Counsail and c
o
duct for M[.]
exploites, having no m
a
of their owne in any p[art of]
these c
o
treis,
t
is like in ex
ience, and so well [.]
for their purpose, as is S
r
Francis Vere. But bo[th .]
will make this motion unto me, they have thought [.]
it best to see first, w
at
answear they shall have [.]
touching
e c
o
tinuing, according to
e C
o
tract,
M
ts
assistance: whereof I thinke there will be
in Co
u
t Maurices l
re
s. I have no[thing]
to certify of any other mater, but
t
Co
u
t Philip [of]
Nassau
, being gone fr
o
hence a moneth agoe, w[ith]
1200 horse and 15000 foote, to wast
e lande of [.]
fol.10r
bourgh, hath sette fire in divers village and relligious
houses, taken divers good prisoners, and as it is reported
(for he himselve hath written nothing) hath surprised
e towne of
S
t
Vitt
, w
c
belongeth to Co
u
t Maurice by
e right of his
mother,
but is no place of any wealth
or import
a
ce otherwise. How Count Philippe
will be able, to make his retraite w
t
out losse of his
people, it is doubted in some sort,
e Enemy, as wee heare,
p
paring to come to him: and yet
e bruite is giv
e
out
at this very instant,
t
he and all his troupes are re-
turned into Guelders.
And thus I take my h
u
ble
leave. Fr
